required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pulse Pressure Variability With Position Before EPIdural Analgesia
clinical_study.official_title: Predictive Value of a Postural Test on Pulse Pressure Variation During Labor With Epidural Analgesia on Fetal Heart Rate Abnormalities

brief_summary.textblock: Fetal heart rate abnormalities are common. Miller et al. have demonstrated that new onset fetal heart rate abnormalities after initial labor epidural dosing occur more frequently in women with a low admission pulse pressure than those with a normal admission pulse. The aim of the present study is to look for a statistical link between the occurrence of a fetal heart abnormality requiring an intervention and maternal hemodynamic factors (blood pressure, pulse pressure, and cardiac output) measured before epidural analgesia in two positions: dorsal decubitus position and in the left lateral decubitus.

primary_outcome.description: Fetal heart rate abnormalities occurring during the first hour of epidural analgesia and requiring an intervention. Relationship between maternal hemodynamic factors (heart rate, blood pressure, pulse pressure, and cardiac output) measured before epidural analgesia in two positions (dorsal decubitus position and in the left lateral decubitus) and fetal heart rate abnormalities occurring during the first hour of epidural analgesia and requiring an intervention.

secondary_outcome.description: Fetal heart rate abnormalities occurring during the labor (>1 hour) and requiring an intervention. Comparison of the prognostic performance of pulse pressure and cardiac output to detect fetal heart rate abnormalities

Relationship between maternal hemodynamic factors (heart rate, blood pressure, pulse pressure, and cardiac output) measured before epidural analgesia in two positions (dorsal decubitus position and in the left lateral decubitus) and mode of delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Newborn heart rate, blood pressure, pulse pressure, and cardiac output
secondary_outcome.description: Relationship between maternal hemodynamic factors (heart rate, blood pressure, pulse pressure, and cardiac output) measured before epidural analgesia in two positions (dorsal decubitus position and in the left lateral decubitus) and newborn health status.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with hemodynamic abnormalities
secondary_outcome.description: Heart rate, blood pressure, pulse pressure, and cardiac output measured before and after epidural analgesia.

intervention.description: Heart rate, arterial pressure and cardiac output measurements (monitor NICOM) performed in the dorsal decubitus position and in the left lateral decubitus

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- pregnant women
- gestational age > 37 weeks
- single eutrophic fetus
- wishing for epidural analgesia
- cervical dilatation less than or equal to 5 cm
- spontaneous labor
- scheduled for a vaginal delivery.
Exclusion Criteria:
- prematurity or post-term birth
- induction of labour using oxytocin or prostaglandin
- contraindication to epidural analgesia
- history of hypertension or gravidic hypertension or heart disorder
- gestational diabetes
- foetal malformation or oligohydramnios or fetal growth abnormality
- hematocrit less than 20%

reference.citation: Miller NR, Cypher RL, Nielsen PE, Foglia LM. Maternal pulse pressure at admission is a risk factor for fetal heart rate changes after initial dosing of a labor epidural: a retrospective cohort study. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2013 Oct;209(4):382.e1-8. doi: 10.1016/j.ajog.2013.05.049. Epub 2013 Jun 13.
